intro: Acacia seyal var. multijuga, commonly known as the pale acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It is characterized by its slender, multi-branched stems and small, yellow flowers that appear in clusters. The plant produces flat, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Its leaves are bipinnate, consisting of numerous tiny, feather-like leaflets. Acacia seyal var. multijuga is well adapted to drought conditions and is often used in traditional medicine and as a source of gum arabic.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia seyal var. multijuga is primarily native to the Horn of Africa, including countries such as Somalia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea. It is also found in parts of Sudan and the Arabian Peninsula. This plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in savannas and rocky areas. It is well adapted to dry climates and can tolerate poor soil conditions. Its natural range extends into some regions of southern Arabia and northern Kenya.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia seyal var. multijuga was mainly introduced to stabilize soil and prevent erosion in arid and semi-arid regions. It is commonly used in reforestation projects due to its fast growth and ability to thrive in poor soil conditions. The plant is also valued for its hardy nature, making it suitable for landscaping and afforestation in challenging environments. Its introduction has helped in restoring degraded lands across parts of Africa and the Middle East. However, it requires careful management to prevent it from becoming invasive in non-native ecosystems.
